title: It's good to show a map on the screen
comment: when running a dashcam in the background. It does have bugs making it not very useful for navigation, and also will crash the display if there's a map rendering error (e.g. NH Lakes Region) though bg service will stay running. Pseudo 3D rendering is horizontally squashed, but acceptable. Doesn't save last state. It is however light on resource consumption and will be rendering a map before most nav apps have even loaded a UI, and runs well on low spec devices that more bloated apps may not even start up on.

title: Nice & Fast Offline°
comment: It's a 5 star for me, even if the interface not too user friendly. What i liked most about this apps, is it's ability to get the latest map available online, aside from the "Offline" voice guided navigation. Offline, meaning the network will not be charging you, it will work 100% with only GPS & "Mobile Data" switched OFF. But for units with only A-GPS, you will be charged of course... I have an OSM account, and from time to time makes an update of routes or roads. I've observed that in lesser days, the updates I've edited on OSM was already shown on the maps using Navit®. So easy, just click on menu "Download Maps" and select the country you wish to download. If there's an update, it will be automatically noticed on the map screen. To the Developers of this Navit®, I salute you all. Excellent job...

Better use your PC to select and download maps, kep them smaller than 1.2GB and push on your device after. If you check the POIs don't hesitate to update the maps from time to time as my favorite local restaurant is now there too!

title: Navit for Android

title: Great open source app
comment: Great free - open source (multi platform) app, with maps from Open Street Map (you can choose other maps if you prefer). It is to GPS navigation what Firefox is for browsing or What VLC is for music.  You don't need to connect your phone to the computer to upload maps (but if you want you can: you don't need to install anything and it doesn't require a specific OS).  You can use it offline without any problem (to search and navigate to your destination), which is especially usefull when you are abroad. With Google Maps or Apple Maps you can't and with Ovi Maps search doesn't work very well offline.  It works fast (on my Motorola Defy, Google Maps often freezes).  Only downside: the menu could be more user friendly. This app deserves to get more mainstream attention.

title: Problematic
comment: Running on an LG Optimus One, I downloaded the maps for Canada (I am in Toronto). At startup, all I saw was a green dot on a field of white. After fiddling around, and zooming out-out-out-out, I finally saw where I was.   The map showed my correct location, which is good. However, I could not find any street, never mind any address, when searching for a route. I was looking for locations that are on major streets and have been there for over 20 years, so obsolete maps should not have been an issue.  I don't know if the problem is the application or the map (I downloaded the map for all of Canada), and there's no way to tell. Unfortunately, the interface isn't very intuitive, and there's no real help, so there's not much I can try.  I suspect that this is one of those applications where it either works great out of the box, or it does not work at all.

title: Great app for those who want to navigate w/out dat
comment: Great free (FLOSS) app for those who want to navigate without using/needing a data connection (roaming - big brother not knowing where you are and where you go). Don't complain if there are no maps for your country, Navit is just the program - add your country details to OSM instead. UI needs some getting used to, it's not a pure android program. It does work fine with streetnames, not with numbers - which are not often in OSM.
